Extent to which climate finance is being accessed (by government and non-government institutions)

Extent to which implementation of comprehensive measures - plans, strategies, policies, programmes and budgets - to achieve low-emission and climate-resilient development objectives has improved.

This project is a low emission capacity building project focuses on strengthening Uganda’s technical and institutional capacity in the development of Green House Gas inventory systems and Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions.
capital of a political entity

1. Thematic working group on GHG inventory system and national dialogue platforms and coordination mechanisms established. 2. Number of Nationally Appropriate Mitigation actions (NAMAs) full proposals in place 3. MRVs for HG inventory systems and NAMAs in place 4. Nationally Determined Contributions developed and sent to UNFCCC

comment.narrative: 1. There are no thematic working groups and dialogue platforms on GHG inventory systems in place. 2. There is no systematic Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMAs) development full proposal yet. 3. There is no MRV for GHG Inventory system and NAMA in place. 4. No Nationally Determined Contributions developed and sent to UNFCCC

1. A GHG inventory and data collection system established and institutionalized, including inventory management capacity built at national level. 2. Bankable proposals with private sector lead business models developed for 4 NAMAs and submitted for financing 3. A National Green growth Strategy developed and operationalized. 4. Nationally Determined Contributions developed and sent to UNFCCC

1. The GHG inventory system was developed with a direct linkage to the Climate Change Department Knowledge Management System (KMS), the national Climate Atlas and Performance Management Framework (PMF). The inventory includes sector specific GHG data and a digital/e-library. 2. The Green Schools NAMA, an integrated sustainable energy solution for schools in Uganda was finalized and submitted to the NAMA Facility. It is a huge potential for GHG emission reductions through the introduction of Institutional Improved Cook Stoves (IICS), which will be introduced in 15,750 Ugandan schools, representing 75% of all Ugandan schools and is worth USD 15 Million. A waste-to energy NAMA concept finalized and submitted to the UNFCCC portal for elaboration of a fully-fledged proposal for funding by GEF. A fuel efficiency and vehicle inspection NAMA was elaborated so that transport and energy efficiency is integrated in NDC, targeting how private sector and financial institutions can be involved and offer financing. For the agriculture sector, a livestock based NAMA was elaborated. 3. The Green Growth strategy was developed and presented for national adoption. 4. The Nationally Determined Contributions were finalized and submitted to the UNFCCC as part of national obligations in the Paris Agreement.

1. A GHG inventory and data collection system established and institutionalized, including inventory management capacity built at national level. 2. Bankable proposals with private sector lead business models developed for 2 NAMAs and submitted for financing 3. A functional National Green growth Strategy . 4. Nationally Determined Contributions developed and sent to UNFCCC

1. A functional GHG inventory and data collection system in place.Project Audit and Project terminal evaluation finalized 2. Bankable proposals (LECB Phase II project document developed) with private sector lead business models developed and submitted for financing 3. A National green growth development strategy in place and launched. 4. Nationally Determined Contributions developed (GHG inventory report in place)

1. No. of contracts between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. No. of Memorandum of understanding signed 3. No. of MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. No of tourism support institutions strengthened

comment.narrative: Tourism has a high potential for income generation and has been identified as one of the priority sectors by Government. However, the tourism sector is still underdeveloped, with a weak policy and regulatory framework; limited access to markets; limited product scope, weak business and technical skills; weak value chains. The following was the project baseline status: 1. Zero contracts between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. Zero Memorandum of understanding signed 3. Zero MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. Zero tourism support institutions strengthened

1. 16 contracts/business linkages between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. 14 Memorandum of understanding signed 3. 20 MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. 5 tourism support institutions strengthened
a. Uganda Tourism Board Strategic Plan 2016/17 - 2020/21 developed b. Kampala Urban Tourism Development Strategy developed c. Inclusive Business Ecosystem for Tourism Mapped

1. 16 contracts/business linkages between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. 14 Memorandum of understanding signed 3. 20 MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. 5 tourism support institutions strengthened a). The Uganda Tourism Strategic Plan 2016/17 - 2020/21 was developed. The Strategy provides a roadmap for translation of the national vision and SDGs into specific interventions. b). The Kampala Urban Tourism Development Strategy was developed. It provides a roadmap for the growth and coordination of urban tourism development in the five divisions of Kampala as well as the establishment of urban tourism support infrastructure. c). A Mapping Study of the Tourism inclusive Business Ecosystem System in Uganda was undertaken. The study provides critical information for the strengthen of the ecosystem to ensure its inclusive and low income persons are able to benefit from participating in the tourism value chain
Project operationally closed

capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Diagnostic study report on the review of the National Environment Management Policy (NEMP), related policies, laws and strategies in place. 2. Draft Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) sectoral guidelines for the energy, agriculture and, mining in place. 3. Strategy for management of Electronic waste in place. 4. Draft national biomass energy strategy in place. 5. Capacity building programme in place 5.1 National institutional capacity needs assessment report for Climate risk management in place and selected government officials trained in Climate risk management. 5.2 Training manual for climate risk management in place and selected government officials trained in Climate risk management.

comment.narrative: 1. The National Environment Management Policy (1994) is in place but not reviewed or updated to cater for emerging environmental challenges. 2. The National Environmental Impact Assessment Regulations are in place but no EIA sectoral guidelines (for agriculture, mining, energy and other key sectors). 3. There is an electronic waste management policy but no strategy for management of electronic waste in place. 4. No national biomass energy strategy in place. 5.1 There is a National Disaster Preparedness and Management Policy and platform in place but there is an inadequate capacity for coordination of Climate risk management. 5.2 Most relevant government officials are inadequately skilled in climate risk management.

1. National Environment Management Policy (NEMP), related policies, laws and strategies in place. e.g. Draft National Environment Management Policy (NEMP) 2. Environment Impact Assessment guidelines for Agriculture, Mining, Energy and Fisheries sectors in place: Wetlands Atlas (Vol I and II) in finalized. 3. Electronic waste strategy in place: Gender strategy for environment, natural resources subsector launched and disseminated. 4. Biomass Energy Strategy in place: Re-branding of the Environment, natural resources sub sector completed. 5. Capacity building programme in place

1. Draft National Environment Management Policy (NEMP) was presented to the Joint Water and Environment Technical Committee for review and onward submission for approval. 2. Electronic waste strategy in place: The Gender strategy for the Environment natural resources sub sector was launched and disseminated. 4. Biomass Energy Strategy in place: New brand (including logo and jingle) for the environment and natural resources sub sector completed. 5. Capacity building programme in place

Uganda The overall goal of the Pulse-Lab Uganda Programme is to increase Resilience and well-being of Ugandan vulnerable populations to economic and other shocks with appropriate Government interventions and responses.This will be by (a) Increasing Gov'ts ability to anticipate potential shocks (b) Increase the ability Ugandan NGOs and Private Sector to analyse &focus resources based on real time data (c) Increase ability of a global network real time data partners within UN and host countries of Pulse Labs to use real time data for development analysis and response.

comment.narrative: No mechanism is presently in place for joint management planning for natural resource use by local governments in the critical landscape

District governments in six districts cooperate effectively to regulate and plan natural resource use over 227389 Ha of the critical landscape resulting in a landscape level coordination mechanism that enshrines biodiversity conservation by mandate

Interdistrict coordination mechanism on enforcement and awareness in place and operational involving district political and technical staff It is coordinated by the Resident District Commissioner of Otuke district for the 4 shea butter tree oilt districts of Kitgum Agago Otuke and Abim

description.narrative: Integrating PA Management in the Wider Landscape
Biodiversity management is factored into decisionmaking governing land use management in District Development Plans

Mechanisms landscape level coordinated management plans and institutional governance systems for enhancing sustainable management of Kidepo critical landscape promoted with landscape management plan in place and enforced

description.narrative: District governments in six districts of Kitgum Kaabong Agago Otuke Abim and Kotido have proven capacity for managing natural resources sustainably

comment.narrative: District Governments lack the competence and staff skills to monitor and enforce laws As a result there is a lack of understanding of the situation visàvis sustainable hunting and Shea utilization leading to habitat degradation

Local Governments have the competence and staff skills to monitor and enforce laws on sustainable hunting and sustainable use of Shea tree in target districts measured by a 40 increase in scores in capacity development scorecard
In order to improve on the competence and staff skills of local governments enforcement officers from one district Otuke were trained during a two days workshop on enforcement

description.narrative: Existence of interdistrict coordination body in place and functioning with an M E Plan

comment.narrative: There is no District coordination mechanism in place leading to a lack of coordination over the management of crucial savannah woodland habitats Shea trees and wildlife

A District coordination mechanism in place in the project target area six districts to ensure that biodiversity management in National Parks Central forest reserves and wildlife migration corridors and dispersal areas is factored into integrated decisionmaking governing land use management

As a first step towards formation of a district coordination mechanism for biodiversity management in National Parks CFRs and wildlife corridors a district task force on enforcement comprising of Resident District Commissioners RDCs and District Environment Officers of Kitgum Agago Otuke Abim Kaabong and Kotido was formed Similarly engagement done with cultural leaders in the six project districts of Abim Kaabong Kotido Otuke Agago and Kitgum was another starting point for formation of an interdistrict coordination mechanism

description.narrative: Management plan including zonation plan and regulations in place

comment.narrative: Management plans and regulations critical for wildlife dispersal are presently nonexistent in the wider landscape

In order to fasten the management planning process for critical dispersal areas and formulation of regulations for BDfriendly management in identified blocks incentives in form of community livelihood improvement projects were initiated whereby four community project proposals were approved for funding

1.National charcoal survey finalized validated, approved and database established The national Charcoal survey was finalized and launched for use in updating the database for parameters in the value chain related to production, marketing and transportation. 2. Framework for institutional coordination and resource mobilization in place. The action plans were developed, approved by District councils and integrated in the DDPs. Draft ordinances have been developed and the process to procure a facilitator for the development of charcoal trading guidelines. The process of reviewing charcoal certification schemes is on-going by UNBS. 3. Awareness and educational program on local ordinances and standards for sustainable charcoal was completed.The communication strategy has been finalized and adopted by the MEMD, and is informing the awareness program now and in the future. 4. 4 districts manage and establish dedicated renewable biomass feed stocks and supply improved kilns with renewable biomass 300of 700 planned sample plots have been established in 2 districts of the project area. The activity is still on-going in the other 2 districts 5.Conservation agriculture practices piloted across 240hectares. Up to 16groups of farmers, each with 20members (505 women), have been introduced to CA , covering at least 15 hectare per group. The farmers have realized doubled yields of maize and beans; with conservation compared to conventional agriculture practices.

comment.narrative: Absence of data on refugee and host community livelihood needs, as well as local government capacity.

1. An assessment of refugee and host community livelihood needs, as well as local government capacity, in order to inform the formulation of an emergency response plan and resilience building programme.
2. An emergency livelihood and local government capacity response programme, in line with the UN’s Refugee Host Populations Empowerment Strategy (REHOPE) in Uganda and the Government’s refugee hosting model, formulated.
Livelihood needs Assessment report for Refugee and Host communities was completed.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: By end 2018, targeted MDAs have adequate technical, functional and financial capacity to integrate and operationalize NRM and climate change mitigation policies and strategies, including: (a) execution of priority gender-responsive investments that increase energy access and consumption efficiency and promote low-carbon and renewable modern energy services; and (b) scale-up of climate change mitigation / adaptation and disaster-risk management strategies 1.1: 63 institutions developed, policies, strategies, and budgets that integrate sustainable energy, natural resource and land management, biodiversity, climate change and DRR mitigation and resilience initiatives (2013 - Sector review reports) 1.2: 20% of sectors and institutions integrating climate change mitigation, disaster-risk recovery and resilience into development plans and budgets (2013 - National climate change finance analysis report; hazard, risk, & vulnerability profile reports) 1.3: Zero districts where local climate change adaptation fund is established and operational to provide financial resources for climate change adaptation interventions (2015 - MoLG data) Output 2: By 2018, MDAs with adequate technical, operational and financial capacities to implement CCR/DRR policies and regulatory frameworks 2.1: There is no harmonized functional national climate information and early warning system (2014 - NECOC) 2.2: There is no existence of a system to access, deliver, monitor, report and verify the use of environmental and climate finance (2013 - Overseas Development Institute reports) 2.3: 10 national/sub-national development and key sectoral plans that explicitly address disaster and/or climate risk management being implemented, disaggregated by those which are gender responsive (2013 - NECOC)
Output 3: By 2018, MDAs with adequate technical, technological, operational and financial capacities to engage the private sector, LGs and CSOs to deliver on gender responsive CCR/DRR innovations 3.1:

Output 2: By 2018, JLOS and UHRC with adequate technical capacities & tools for effective human rights promotion & protection and achievement of equitable and sustained access to justice; and the Electoral Commission with strengthened Capacities & tools to implement electoral laws and ensure free and credible elections. 1.1.2.1: (a): Zero number of courts connected to the Court Case Administration System (CCAS) - (2015) JLOS Report, (b): No Human Rights Information System(HURIS) at the UHRC - (2015) Human Rights Report (c): No Electoral Complaints Management System (ECMS) at EC - (2015)Parliamentary Commission Annual Report, 1.1.2.2: 38 (2016) Number of districts in Northern and Eastern Uganda with a complete chain of frontline JLOS services (Police Station, Prosecution/legal aid, adjudication and Prison) - JLOS Reports 1.1.2.3: HRC and Electoral Commission partially meet minimum core function performance benchmarks (2013) - HR Performance Reports 1.1.2.4: 14% Proportion of HR cases disposed

Output 1 1. 50% of the bills completed 2. 39% of enacted laws that are implemented 3. 95.8% of completed to registered cases 4. 2 bills that are human rights compliant enacted into laws 5. Electoral Commission Partially (2) meet the minimum core function performance benchmarks. 6. Evidence that the process of operationalizing a functional Leadership forum(Parliament, Elders forum) has started Output 2 1. 4 democracy institutions with functional e-governance systems 2. 60 districts in Northern and Eastern Uganda with a complete chain of frontline Output 3 1. There is progress of establishing an inclusive and functional Civil Society’s engagement platform in place. 2. 35 Members of Parliament and 10 CSOs equipped with knowledge and advocacy skills on accountability for gender laws and policies Output 4 1. 769 number of LCI, II and III court officials trained 2. 26% of cases are disposed through alternative dispute resolutions 3. 3 country diagnostic studies are conducted to inform policy options on national response to sustainability and scalable models.

1. Five (5) analytical/diagnostic studies were conducted and they informed policy options on national response to sustainability and scalable models. 2. Parliament held a radio talk show and a panel discussion on the theme: “Democratic Governance and SDGs in Uganda: Challenges and Prospects”. This sensitized Members of parliament about Parliament’s role in the implementation of the 2030 Global Agenda. Consequently, a motion to debate the role of Parliament in implementation of the SDGs was moved in Parliamentary session of the day. In addition, Newspaper supplements were also run in the New vision and Daily Monitor. 3. Trained 23 Journalists (12 Female and 10 Male) under Training of Trainers (TOT) in evidence based, development reporting and conflict sensitive journalism focused on human rights and rule of law. i. Parliament held an intensive Post –Elections Induction Seminar for Members of the 10th Parliament. The Induction equipped the newly-elected members with necessary knowledge and information on; ii. The doctrine of separation of powers, checks & balances iii. The role of Parliament in national governance iv. The legislative process v. Parliamentary practices &procedures, privileges, immunities and etiquette. vi. The National Development Plan, vii. Budgeting process and the Sustainable Development Goals.
4. Trained Programme team 28 people (10 Female & 18 Male) in the areas of Human Rights Based Approach, Equal Opportunities and Gender Equality for programme development, planning and implementation. 5. The Electoral Commission’s (EC) capacity was enhanced. Technical experts in voter and civic education, conflict resolution, and public relations and media were employed by UNDP and deployed to the EC. This boosted public trust in the EC and subsequently accounted for a larger voter turnout during the 2016 national election. To-date the EC partially meet the minimum core function performance bench marks. 6. One (01) democracy institution has a functional e-

1.1 Number of frameworks for environmental management, those in existence are fragmented and individualized. 1.2 Existence of inter-ministerial/agencies coordination on the implementation of Rio Conventions. 2.1 Existence of consistent Institutional capacities for managing the Rio Conventions, well streamlined and scaled up. 3.1. Access to environmental data by end-users not comprehensive. Available systems for environmental data collection, analysis, and sharing in place but not unified and data are not easily accessible 3.2 Existence of an agreed environmental clear house unified system for improved implementation and reporting of the Rio Conventions

comment.narrative: 1.1 No frameworks for environmental management, those in existence are fragmented and individualized. 1.2 Limited inter-ministerial/agencies coordination on the implementation of Rio Conventions. 2.1 No clear consistent Institutional capacities for managing the Rio Conventions, few are projectised and piecemeal 3.1. Limited access to environmental data by end-users not comprehensive. Available systems for environmental data collection, analysis, and sharing in place but not unified and data are not easily accessible 3.2 No clear house mechanism exist in NEMA for the Biodiversity area.

1.1 Two (2) Proposed institutional frameworks are approved and implemented 1.2 Formal Inter-ministerial cooperation on the implementation of Rio Conventions in place. Specifically; Satisfactory trainees’ evaluation of the implementation of the proposed inter-ministerial cooperation protocols. 4 inter-ministerial cooperation protocols on the implementation of Rio Conventions are in place, tested and adopted by the State agencies.
2.1 institutional and technical capacities to create knowledge and monitor the implementation of Rio Conventions in place. Annual dialogues involving men and women held by quarters 4,7,10, 13. Capacities of at least 4 institutions and 150 (females and males) are enhanced. At least 30% of the staff trained are women.
3.1 A unified system for monitoring the implementation of Rio Conventions and reporting on them is established and operational.
3.2 Sectoral environmental data (system) is accessible to end users in a comprehensive and policy-relevant way.

1.1 Zero: Of Two (2) Proposed institutional frameworks are approved and implemented( Project inception held instead) 1.2 Zero: Formal Inter-ministerial cooperation on the implementation of Rio Conventions in place. Specifically; Satisfactory trainees’ evaluation of the implementation of the proposed inter-ministerial cooperation protocols. No inter-ministerial cooperation protocols on the implementation of Rio Conventions are in place, tested and adopted by the State agencies.
2.1 Zero: (0). institutional and technical capacities to create knowledge and monitor the implementation of Rio Conventions in place. No annual dialogues involving men and women held by quarters. No capacities of at least institutions held no staff trained .
3.1 No unified system for monitoring the implementation of Rio Conventions and reporting on them is established and operational.
3.2 No Sectoral environmental data (system) is accessible to end users in a comprehensive and policy-relevant way.

Output 1 1.1: Wetlands and natural grasslands rehabilitated 1.2: Surface areas restored, rehabilitated or enriched with grassed, herbaceous and wooded vegetation, reducing loss of top soil, protecting riverbanks and improving infiltration in critical areas.
Output 2 2.1: Percentage increase in agricultural incomes and alternative livelihoods in the project sites. 2.2: Number of women involved in livelihoods and employability interventions in the project sites.
Output 3 3.1: % of population with access to improved climate information and drought, flood and severe storm warnings (disaggregated by gender). 3.2: Number of early flood warning systems installed in vulnerable communities.
